params.text:
Reading

Develop Reading Strategies

Language in Action

• Develop reading techniques
    (skimming vs. scanning)
  • Create mind maps
  • Learn basic linking words
Reading: Introduction

Welcome! In this module, you'll learn some special skills to understand what you read.

Here's what we'll cover:

1. Skimming & Scanning: These are special ways to quickly look through a text to find the information you need.

  2. Mind Maps: We'll learn how to create mind maps to organize the information you find in your reading.

  3. Linking Words: Special words that help you connect ideas in a text.
Develop Reading Techniques (Skimming & Scanning)

Skimming and scanning are 2 useful ways to read information.
Please click on the information points to find out more:
Skimming for Key Information
Scanning for Specifics:
• Think of keywords like clues that relate to the information you're looking for.

You don't have time to read every detail, but you need to understand the main points.
Skimming in reading is similar!
Focus on Titles and Headings:
Read the First Sentence:
• These act like headlines in a business report, summarizing the main idea of a section.
• Often, the first sentence of a paragraph introduces the main topic.
This is like searching an invoice for a particular amount or a contract for a specific date.
Identify Keywords:
Pay Attention to Numbers and Dates:
• These are often crucial details in business documents.
Develop Reading Techniques - Sentences

params.textField:
If you're scanning a meeting agenda for a specific deadline, you would look for *dates* and times to find the relevant information.
If you're scanning a business proposal for a specific product name, you would quickly look for that product *name* in the document.
The first sentence of a business report might say "Sales for the past quarter *increased* by 10%." 
While skimming a business email, you might look for headings like "Meeting Agenda," "*Action* Items," or "Important Update" to find the key *points* quickly.

params.textField: Sometimes you don't need to read *every* word. Be a super reader and learn to skim and *scan*! Skimming is like looking at pictures in a book to get the main idea. Look at *titles* and first sentences to understand the important parts. Scanning is like *finding* your friend at a park. You look for something specific, like a *name* or a number. This helps you find the information you need *quickly*!

metadata.title: Develop Reading Techniques 1 - Drag the words

params.text: Create Mind Maps: Key Points
Work can be busy! Sometimes you have a lot of information to remember. A mind map can help you organize your work, just like a secretary uses a filing cabinet. Here's how:
Big Word in the Middle:
Draw Lines Out:
• In the center, write the main thing you're reading about.
Short Words on the Lines:
• From the center, draw lines for the important things you learn about the product.
• On each line, write short words to remember the details.
Mind Maps - Sentences

params.text: Mind Maps: Forum & Quiz

You are on an online forum where people are discussing mind maps.
Please read the posts and answer the questions:

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: Bryan uses mind maps to:
answers:
Remember important points from meetings. 

Write emails about new products.

Order office supplies.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What does Abigail write in the center of her mind map about a new product?
answers:
The name of the new product. 

The date she received the email. 

The color of the product.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Why does Micah like to use mind maps before presentations?
answers:
To organize his thoughts and remember what to say. 

To draw pictures for the audience.

To practice speaking English.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text: Micah:
Abigail:
Micah: "Before presentations, I make mind maps with the main ideas. Then I add details for each point. It helps me organize my thoughts and remember what to say. Mind maps are great!"

Abigail: "I use mind maps to understand emails about new products. The main product goes in the center, then I write details like price and color on lines branching out. It helps me see everything at once!"
Bryan: "Mind maps help me remember things from work meetings. I write the main topic in the middle, then draw lines for important points. It's like a colorful map for my brain!"
Bryan:

params.textField:
The meeting starts at 10:00 AM. *Then*, we will send you a summary email. 
The company is located in New York City. *We have offices* in London and Paris too. 
The price of the product is very good. *So*, it's a good option for our customers. 
We got your order yesterday. *Today*, we will start working on it. 
Do you have any questions? *We can help you*!

params.textField: Open plan offices are becoming more *popular*. Companies like to have all their employees working in one big space. *This* can help with communication and teamwork. *But*, it can also be noisy and distracting. *So*, some people prefer to have private offices. *No matter* what type of office you work in, it's important to be respectful of your colleagues.

metadata.title: Learn Basic Linking Words 1 - Drag the words

params.text: Module Summary Quiz
Choose the BEST answer for each question to show what you learned in this module.

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: What do you do when you skim a text?
answers:
Look for titles and first sentences to find the main idea. 

Read every word carefully. 

Spend a lot of time reading all the details.

choices.question: Question 2 of 6: What can help you scan a document quickly?
answers:
Look for keywords related to what you're looking for. 

Read the whole document first. 

Write a summary of everything you read.

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: What do you write in the center of a mind map?
answers:
The main subject you're reading about. 

A long paragraph about the topic. 

A list of questions you have about the topic.

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: How can mind maps help you with your work?
answers:
They help you remember important details and see connections. 

They make your desk look colorful. 

They allow you to write emails faster.

choices.question: Question 5 of 6: The meeting starts at 10:00 AM. We will send you a summary email __________.
answers:
Then. 

So we can start on time. 

Because it's important.

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: The price is good. _________ it's a popular choice.
